physDesc.p: This is a one page letter. On the left upper corner, it is written Harriet's address: “Miss Harriet Monroe, Poetry 543 Cass Street, Chicago, Ill.” There is a faint print on the upper part of the paper.

div.p: Your postal has come to-day. I thank you very much for telling me about the guarantors’ copies. I wonder whether you are still sending copies to Mrs. Charles B. Perkins, Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts, and to Miss Annie Chapman, Poplars,Rickmansworth,Herts, England. If not, I shall be very glad indeed if you would send copies to these people.
I enjoyed Sandburg’s war poem very much. I think perhaps it was a little uneven in spots, but I was very glad to have made way for anything so good.

By the way I have had a somewhat unfortunate experience with that M. de Lanux whom I wrote about. He turned our to be rather a laze fellow, and I am happy to learn from Martyn Johnson that "The Dial" has had the same difficulty with him. I have, therefore, severed my connections with him. Th (sic) translation of his poems I have seen, and they do not strike me as good, but as I wrote you before the originals which I saw first are quite charming. I tell you all this in order that you may know how I stand in regard to him should he send you these poems. I know you would not take them on my account unless you liked them, but still if you thought he were a friend of mine, you might be more inclined to loon upon his work with a favorable eye. I think his original verses alone, however, would repay you if you wish to publish them, but I would not touch the translations, if I were you. It is immaterial to me what you do as far as he is concerned.
